inlineContent.text: A variety of initializers and methods are available for string and numeric representation,
Mathematical operators are available between two instances:
Comparison operators are available between two instances:
can be formed between two instances
Many more features are detailed in the documentation
TimecodeKit is designed to work with Xcode’s autocomplete fluidly. Beginning a
initializer with a period will produce a list of all available source time value types.
Timecode can be formed by providing discrete values.

code: .components(d: 00, h: 01, m: 00, s: 00, f: 00, sf: 00) // days and subframes allowed

inlineContent.text: Timecode can be formed by converting from a variety of common time values.

code: // real time (wall clock) elapsed in seconds
// elapsed audio samples at a given sample rate in Hz
// AVFoundation AVAsset: read .start, .end or .duration timecode of a movie
// rational time fraction (ie: Final Cut Pro XML, or AAF)

inlineContent.text: The frame rate must also be supplied. This can be done easily with the
If additional properties need to be specified, supply a

code: let tc = try Timecode(.string("01:00:00:00"), using: properties)

inlineContent.text: It is possible to clamp to valid timecode using a non-throwing init.

code: // clamp full timecode to valid range
Timecode(.components(h: 26, m: 00, s: 00, f: 00), at: .fps24, by: .clamping)
// clamp individual timecode component values to valid values if they are out-of-bounds
Timecode(.components(h: 01, m: 00, s: 85, f: 50), at: .fps24, by: .clampingEach)

inlineContent.text: It is also possible to wrap to valid timecode using a non-throwing init.

code: // wrap around clock continuously if entire timecode overflows or underflows
Timecode(.components(h: 26, m: 00, s: 00, f: 00), at: .fps24, by: .wrapping)
Timecode(.components(h: 23, m: 59, s: 59, f: 24), at: .fps24, by: .wrapping)
